general.name: Munich House of Artists at Lenbachplatz
general.description: Art, culture & enjoyment are the guiding principles of the varied cultural programme at the Munich Künstlerhaus on Lenbachplatz. Concerts, lectures, cabaret, theatre performances, festivals and art exhibitions take place here. Since its inauguration in 1900 by Prince Regent Luitpold of Bavaria, the Künstlerhaus has fulfilled the main idea of its founding fathers: it serves as a meeting place for artists and society. The neo-Renaissance building, designed by Gabriel von Seidl, remains a historical monument to the turn of the century.

offline.ticket_info: Varies by event; tickets available online or at the box office
offline.event: Regular cultural program including chamber concerts, readings, cabaret, and the annual Gauklerball

general.name: MaximiliansForum
general.description: The MaximiliansForum is a unique public art space located in the pedestrian underpass at Maximilianstraße/Altstadtring in central Munich. It serves as a free, open-air gallery for applied arts including jewellery, design, fashion, and architecture, and showcases innovative contemporary concepts. With its continuously visible exhibitions and occasional performances, it blends art with the urban environment. The space also hosts panel discussions, workshops, and events that invite dialogue around socially and culturally relevant themes. As an accessible and dynamic cultural venue, it reflects Munich’s vibrant arts scene.

offline.opening_hours: Accessible 24/7; exhibitions visible continuously; some events have specific schedules.:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
offline.ticket_info: Free entry; open access as a public art space.:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

transport.parking: Public parking around Altstadtring and Maximilianstraße

offline.event: Rotating exhibitions and cultural events; latest exhibition CLAY CLUB SCHMIDT runs until Jan 22, 2026.

general.name: Haus des Deutschen Ostens (House of the German East)
general.description: The Haus des Deutschen Ostens (HDO) is an institution of the Free State of Bavaria dedicated to preserving and documenting the history and culture of Germans from Central, Eastern, and South-Eastern Europe. It hosts exhibitions, lectures, and educational events and houses a specialized library with over 75,000 media units. The HDO serves as a central meeting place for dialogue between Bavaria and its eastern neighbors.

offline.opening_hours: Exhibitions: Mon-Thu 10:00-20:00, Fri 10:00-15:00; Library hours vary

transport.nearest_station: Rosenheimer Platz (S-Bahn all lines) or Deutsches Museum (Tram 16)
transport.parking: Limited street parking; Gasteig parking garage nearby

offline.event: Arabica und Muckefuck; Virtuelles Museum der Schwarzmeerdeutschen

general.name: Lothringer 13 (Hall for International Contemporary Art)
general.description: Lothringer 13 Halle is an institution for international contemporary art run by the City of Munich. Located in a former industrial premises in Haidhausen, it serves as a platform for group exhibitions and projects that address current social discourses. The space encourages participation and dialogue through a diverse program of art, lectures, and screenings, often supporting new and experimental formats.

general.name: Architekturgalerie (Architecture Gallery)
general.description: The Architekturgalerie München is a dedicated platform for the discussion of architecture, urban planning, and spatial art. Through exhibitions, lectures, and events, it explores current architectural themes and their social relevance. Recently relocated to the 'Bunker' at Blumenstraße, it provides a unique setting for presenting innovative concepts and fostering dialogue between architects, artists, and the public.

general.name: Münchner Kaiserburg im Alten Hof (Munich Imperial Castle in the Old Courtyard)
Pinakothek der Moderne (Pinacotheca of the Modern)
general.description: The Pinakothek der Moderne unites four major museums under one roof: the Collection of Modern Art, the State Graphic Collection, the Architecture Museum, and Die Neue Sammlung (The Design Museum). As one of the largest venues for art, architecture, and design in Europe, it offers a transdisciplinary program that explores cultural movements of the 20th and 21st centuries. The building's glass rotunda serves as a central meeting place and starting point for visitors.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; use public garages (e.g., Heßstraße)

general.name: Staatsgalerie im Neuen Schloss Schleißheim - Europäische Barockmalerei
general.description: The Staatsgalerie inside the New Palace Schleißheim presents European Baroque painting of the highest order. The collection features major works by Flemish, Italian, French, and Spanish masters, displayed within the magnificent historic halls of the palace built by Elector Max Emanuel. The interplay between the palatial architecture and the art collection offers a unique glimpse into the courtly culture of the 17th and 18th centuries.

offline.ticket_info: Regular: 6€; Reduced: 5€; Combo ticket (all palaces): 10€/8€; Under 18: Free

transport.nearest_station: Oberschleißheim (S1) + Bus 292 (Schloss Lustheim) or 15 min walk
transport.parking: Paid parking available at the palace

general.name: Altes Schloss Schleißheim - 'Das Gottesjahr und seine Feste' - Ökumenische Sammlung Gertrud Weinhold
general.description: Housed in the Old Palace Schleißheim, the Gertrud Weinhold Collection 'The Year of God and its Festivals' is an ecumenical exhibition comparing religious customs and festivals worldwide. It displays devotional objects, calendars, and festive items from Christianity, Judaism, Islam, and Buddhism. The collection documents the similarities and specific traditions of global faiths, fostering cross-cultural understanding through the lens of the religious calendar.

offline.ticket_info: Regular: 4€; Reduced: 3€ (Ticket includes Prussia collection); Under 18: Free

transport.parking: Paid parking available at the palace

general.name: Altes Schloss Schleißheim - 'Es war ein Land ...'- Sammlung zur Landeskunde Ost- und Westpreußens
general.description: Located in the Old Palace Schleißheim, this collection is dedicated to the cultural history and regional studies of East and West Prussia. The exhibition 'Es war ein Land...' (There was a land...) preserves the heritage of these former German territories through artifacts such as amber works, silver, ceramics, and historical documents. It provides insight into the daily life, crafts, and history of the region before 1945.

offline.ticket_info: Regular: 4€; Reduced: 3€ (Ticket includes Weinhold collection); Under 18: Free

transport.parking: Paid parking available at the palace

general.name: Städtisches Atelierhaus am Domagkpark / Domagkateliers
general.description: The Domagkateliers is one of Munich's largest artist colonies, located on the grounds of the former Funkkaserne. It provides subsidized studio space for over 100 artists working in various disciplines. The center serves as a vibrant cultural hub, hosting regular art exhibitions, open studio days, and events in the exhibition hall 'halle50', fostering direct exchange between artists and the public.

offline.opening_hours: Exhibitions usually open 'Künstlersonntag' (3rd Sun of month) 14:00-18:00; Office Mon 13-17, Tue 10-17

general.name: Pfefferminzmuseum (Peppermint Museum)
general.description: Located in Eichenau, once a major center for peppermint cultivation in Europe, this museum documents the history of the 'Eichenauer Minze'. Exhibits illustrate the cultivation, harvesting, and drying processes of the medicinal plant, featuring historical machinery and documents. Visitors can learn about the economic importance of peppermint to the region and often sample the local tea.

offline.event: Special tours for groups by appointment

general.name: Otto-König-von-Griechenland-Museum (Otto King of Greece Museum)
general.description: This museum in Ottobrunn is dedicated to Otto of Wittelsbach, the Bavarian prince who became the first King of Greece (1832–1862). The exhibition explores his reign, the phenomenon of Philhellenism in Bavaria, and the history of Ottobrunn's settlement. It serves as a testament to the historical and cultural ties between Bavaria and Greece.

general.name: Otto-König-von-Griechenland-Museum (Otto King of Greece Museum)
general.description: This museum in Ottobrunn is dedicated to Otto of Wittelsbach, the Bavarian prince who became the first King of Greece (1832–1862). The exhibition explores his reign, the phenomenon of Philhellenism in Bavaria, and the history of Ottobrunn's settlement. It serves as a testament to the historical and cultural ties between Bavaria and Greece.

general.name: Diabetesmuseum München (Diabetes Museum Munich)
general.description: The Diabetesmuseum documents the history of diabetes mellitus, its diagnosis, and its treatment over the centuries. The collection includes historical insulin syringes, blood sugar measuring devices, and diaries that provide insight into the daily lives of patients in the past. It serves as an educational resource on the medical and social history of the disease.

general.name: Üblacker Häusl
general.description: The Üblacker Häusl is a historic 'Herbergshaus' (hostel/workers' cottage) dating back to the late 18th century. It stands as one of the few remaining examples of the simple living conditions of day laborers in the Haidhausen district. The building has been restored and now serves as a museum with two historical rooms and a gallery space for contemporary art exhibitions.

general.name: Altes Schloss Schleißheim (Old Schleißheim Castle)
general.description: The Old Palace is the origin of the Schleißheim palace complex, founded by Duke Wilhelm V as a hermitage in the late 16th century. Reconstructed after WWII, it now houses two significant branches of the Bavarian National Museum: the Ecumenical Collection of Gertrud Weinhold (religious festivals) and the Collection of East and West Prussia (cultural history).

offline.event: Permanent exhibitions: Weinhold Collection & Prussia Collection

general.name: Valentin-Karlstadt-Musäum (Valentin Karlstadt Museum)
general.description: Located in the historic Isartor tower, this museum is dedicated to the legendary Munich comedian Karl Valentin and his partner Liesl Karlstadt. The 'Musäum' (a deliberate misspelling) reflects their absurd humor, displaying personal items, stage props, and curious artifacts like the 'Winter Toothpick'. It also features a small cinema and the cozy 'Turmstüberl' café.

general.name: Cuvilliés-Theater in der Residenz München
general.description: The Cuvilliés Theatre is the most significant Rococo theatre in Germany, designed by François de Cuvilliés the Elder. Originally built in the 18th century, its magnificent carved and gilded tier boxes were saved from WWII destruction and reinstalled in the Residenz. It remains a venue for opera and concerts and is open for viewing as a museum.

offline.opening_hours: Varies by season; Apr-Oct usually daily 9-18 or 14-18; Winter daily 14-17 (Check website)

general.name: Marstallmuseum auf Schloss Nymphenburg (Marstallmuseum at Nymphenburg Palace)
general.description: Housed in the historic southern cavalier building of Nymphenburg Palace, the Marstallmuseum contains one of the world's most significant collections of court carriages. The exhibition showcases the magnificent state coaches, sleighs, and riding accessories of the Wittelsbach rulers, including the coronation coach of Emperor Charles VII and the fairytale sleighs of King Ludwig II.

offline.opening_hours: Apr-Mid Oct: Daily 9:00-18:00; Mid Oct-Mar: Daily 10:00-16:00

transport.parking: Large public parking lot at the palace

general.name: Schloss Dachau (Dachau Castle)
general.description: Schloss Dachau is a former summer residence of the Bavarian rulers, situated on a hill with a panoramic view of Munich and the Alps. Originally a medieval castle, it was transformed into a Renaissance palace. The highlight is the Banqueting Hall featuring a magnificent Renaissance wooden ceiling, one of the finest of its kind in southern Germany.

transport.nearest_station: Dachau (S2) + Bus 719/720/722 to Rathaus or Schloss

offline.event: Classical concerts in the Renaissance Hall

general.name: Museum Nymphenburger Porzellan auf Schloss Nymphenburg
general.description: Located on the upper floor of the Marstallmuseum, this museum houses the Bäuml Collection, the most significant public collection of Nymphenburg porcelain. With over 1,000 exhibits, it showcases the artistic development of the porcelain manufactory from its founding in 1747 through the 20th century, featuring delicate Rococo figurines and Neoclassical services.

offline.opening_hours: Apr-Mid Oct: Daily 9:00-18:00; Mid Oct-Mar: Daily 10:00-16:00
offline.ticket_info: Regular: 6€; Reduced: 5€; Combo with Marstallmuseum available

transport.parking: Public parking lot at the palace

general.name: Residenzmuseum München (Munich Residence)
general.description: The Residenzmuseum is one of the most important palace museums in Europe, located in the former city palace of the Bavarian dukes, electors, and kings. Visitors can explore a vast complex of apartments, ceremonial rooms, and chapels representing styles from the Renaissance to Neoclassicism. Highlights include the Antiquarium (the largest Renaissance hall north of the Alps), the Ancestral Gallery, and the Imperial Rooms.

general.name: Schlosspark Nymphenburg: Amalienburg, Badenburg, Pagodenburg, Magdalenenklause
general.description: Hidden within the vast Nymphenburg Palace Park are four unique park pavilions or 'Parkburgen'. The Amalienburg is a Rococo hunting lodge with a Hall of Mirrors; the Badenburg features a grand tiled indoor swimming pool; the Pagodenburg is decorated with chinoiserie; and the Magdalenenklause is built as an artificial ruin for contemplation. These architectural gems offer an intimate glimpse into the courtly leisure of the 18th century.

general.name: Münchner Feuerwehrausstellung (Munich Fire Brigade Museum)
general.description: Located at the historic main fire station (Hauptfeuerwache), this museum presents the history of firefighting in Munich. Exhibits include historic uniforms, helmets, equipment, and vehicles, as well as dramatic displays like a burnt-out subway car from a 1980s fire. It provides insight into the development of fire protection and the daily work of the Munich Fire Department.

general.name: Apothekarium Neubiberg
general.description: The Apothekarium is a private museum dedicated to the history of pharmacy. It houses a collection of historical pharmaceutical vessels, tools, and laboratory equipment, along with a medicinal herb garden. The museum offers a journey through the evolution of medicine production and the profession of the apothecary.

general.name: Museum Haus der Donauschwaben
general.description: This museum documents the history, culture, and fate of the Danube Swabians (Donauschwaben). The collection includes traditional costumes, household items, tools, and documents that trace their settlement in the Danube region, their life there, and their flight and expulsion after WWII. It serves as a center for remembrance and cultural preservation.

general.name: MVG Museum (Munich Transport Museum)
general.description: The MVG Museum showcases the history of Munich's public transport system. Housed in a former tram depot, it displays over 25 historic trams, buses, and utility vehicles. Interactive exhibits include a subway simulator and displays on the evolution of the transport network, uniforms, and signage. A shuttle bus service often connects the museum to the Giesing station on opening days.

transport.parking: No dedicated parking; use public transport

general.name: Ruhmeshalle und Bavaria (Hall of Fame and Bavaria Statue)
general.description: Overlooking the Theresienwiese, the Ruhmeshalle (Hall of Fame) honors distinguished Bavarians with portrait busts. In front stands the colossal bronze statue of Bavaria, the patroness of the state. Visitors can climb inside the statue for a unique view of the Oktoberfest grounds and the city through the lion's mouth.

general.name: Spielzeugmuseum München (Toy Museum)
general.description: Located in the tower of the Old Town Hall on Marienplatz, the Spielzeugmuseum houses the Ivan Steiger collection. Spread over four floors accessed by a spiral staircase, the museum displays historic toys from Europe and America, including dolls, teddy bears, model trains, and tin toys. It offers a nostalgic journey through the history of play.

general.name: Schlossmuseum Ismaning
general.description: The Schlossmuseum Ismaning is located in the Gärtnerhaus of the Ismaning Palace park. It documents the history of the town and the palace, which served as the summer residence for the Bishops of Freising and later the Leuchtenberg family. Exhibits include porcelain, furniture, and objects related to the local paper industry and agriculture.

general.name: Bezirksmuseum Dachau (District Museum Dachau)
general.description: The Bezirksmuseum Dachau focuses on the cultural history of the Dachau region. It presents exhibitions on folklore, crafts, religious customs, and the history of the town, including its significance as an artists' colony. The museum is known for its collection of amulets and religious folk art.

general.name: Jüdisches Museum München (Jewish Museum Munich)
general.description: The Jewish Museum Munich provides an overview of Munich's Jewish history and culture. Part of the Jewish Centre at Sankt-Jakobs-Platz, the museum features a permanent exhibition 'Voices_Places_Times' that explores Jewish identity and history in the city, alongside changing temporary exhibitions on diverse themes ranging from art to social issues.

general.name: Artothek & Bildersaal
general.description: The Artothek allows citizens to rent contemporary artworks for their homes, functioning like a library for art. The attached Bildersaal (Picture Hall) hosts regular exhibitions of Munich-based artists, promoting the local art scene. It is a unique institution that makes art accessible and supports living artists.

offline.opening_hours: Wed 14:00-19:00, Thu 13:00-18:00, Fri 14:00-18:00; Check for Saturday hours
offline.ticket_info: Free admission to exhibitions; Art rental fees apply

general.name: Sudetendeutsches Museum
general.description: Opened in 2020, this museum chronicles the history and culture of the Germans in Bohemia, Moravia, and Sudeten Silesia. The permanent exhibition spans over 1,000 years, covering life in the region, the expulsion after World War II, and the integration of Sudeten Germans into post-war Germany. It features modern architecture and interactive displays.

offline.ticket_info: Regular: 5€; Reduced: 3€ (Currently often free - check website)

transport.parking: Gasteig garage (currently under construction) or Motorama

general.name: BIOTOPIA Lab
general.description: The BIOTOPIA Lab is an interim platform and experiment space for the planned BIOTOPIA - Naturkundemuseum Bayern. Located in the Botanical Garden, it offers workshops, exhibitions, and events that explore the intersection of life sciences, art, and design. It serves as a testing ground for new concepts of science communication and public engagement.

offline.ticket_info: Lab is free; Botanical Garden admission required (approx 5€)

general.name: DG Kunstraum (Deutsche Gesellschaft für christliche Kunst)
general.description: The DG Kunstraum is an exhibition space run by the German Society for Christian Art. It focuses on contemporary art that engages with existential and spiritual questions. The gallery presents changing exhibitions of modern and contemporary artists, fostering a dialogue between art, religion, and society.

general.name: AMUSEUM of Contemporary Art
general.description: The AMUSEUM of Contemporary Art is Germany's first museum dedicated to the Urban Art and Street Art movement. Located in the university district, it showcases works by internationally renowned street artists such as Banksy, Shepard Fairey, and Invader. The museum aims to document and present the history and diversity of this art form.

general.name: Museum für Abgüsse Klassischer Bildwerke (Museum of Casts of Classical Statues)
general.description: This museum houses a collection of plaster casts of famous Greek and Roman sculptures. Originally established for academic study, it offers visitors the chance to see faithful reproductions of masterpieces from museums around the world in one place. The collection provides a comprehensive overview of the history of ancient sculpture.

general.name: Museum Mensch und Natur (Museum of Man and Nature)
general.description: Located in the north wing of Nymphenburg Palace, this family-friendly museum explores the history of the earth and life, as well as the nature of the human being. Interactive exhibits cover topics like genetics, nerves and brain function, earthquakes, and minerals, making complex science accessible to all ages. The museum is a forerunner to the planned BIOTOPIA center and offers a diverse program of special exhibitions and educational workshops. Highlight exhibits include 'JJ1' (Bruno the Bear) and extensive dioramas of local wildlife.

offline.opening_hours: Tue, Wed, Fri 9:00-17:00; Thu 9:00-20:00; Sat-Sun 10:00-18:00; Closed Mon

transport.parking: Large public parking lot at Nymphenburg Palace

offline.event: Special exhibitions on natural history themes

general.name: Münchner Stadtmuseum (Munich City Museum)
general.description: The Münchner Stadtmuseum is the largest municipal museum in Germany, dedicated to the history and culture of Munich. Its collections include photography, puppet theater / fairground attractions, fashion, musical instruments, and urban history. **Note: The main museum building is currently closed for major renovation (until approx. 2031).** Selected exhibitions and the Filmmuseum continue to operate or are presented at interim locations like the 'Zeughaus'.

offline.opening_hours: Main building closed. Filmmuseum/Zeughaus: Tue-Sun 10:00-18:00 (Check website)
offline.ticket_info: Varies by interim location; Filmmuseum tickets sold separately

general.name: Alpines Museum des Deutschen Alpenvereins (Alpine Museum)
general.description: Located on the Prater Island in the Isar river, the Alpine Museum explores the history of mountaineering and the cultural significance of the Alps. Following a major renovation, the museum presents a modern permanent exhibition 'Darum Berge' (Why Mountains) which delves into the human fascination with high altitudes, alpinism, and ecology. The complex also houses the German Alpine Club's archive and library, along with a scenic garden and café.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; use public transport

general.name: Kunstverein München
general.description: Founded in 1823, the Kunstverein München is one of Germany's oldest contemporary art associations. Located in the historic arcades of the Hofgarten, it serves as a platform for experimental and international contemporary art. The institution focuses on presenting emerging artists and new discourses through rotating exhibitions, lectures, and publications, fostering a lively exchange between artists and the public.

general.name: Museum Mineralogia München - Kristalle in Natur und Technik
general.description: The Museum Mineralogia, part of the Bavarian State Collection for Mineralogy, showcases the world of minerals, crystals, and meteorites. Exhibits highlight both the aesthetic beauty of gemstones and the scientific relevance of minerals in technology and industry. Notable displays include large meteorites, fluorescent minerals, and rotating special exhibitions on topics like volcanism or extraterrestrial materials.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

general.name: Flugwerft Schleißheim - Museum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (Aviation Museum)
general.description: A branch of the Deutsches Museum, the Flugwerft Schleißheim is located on one of Germany's oldest airfields. The museum combines the restored historic command center and hangars from 1912 with a modern exhibition hall. It displays over 70 aircraft, ranging from the early days of aviation and WWI fighters to VTOL jets and helicopters, alongside a functioning restoration workshop viewable by visitors.

transport.parking: Free parking available at the museum

general.name: Staatliches Museum Ägyptischer Kunst (State Museum of Egyptian Art)
general.description: The SMÄK is one of the world's most important collections of ancient Egyptian art, housed in a spectacular subterranean building in the Kunstareal. The museum focuses on the art and sculpture of ancient Egypt rather than just cultural history, displaying masterpieces like the golden treasure of Queen Amanishakheto. The modern architecture creates an atmospheric journey through 5,000 years of history, with halls dedicated to pharaohs, the afterlife, and religion.

transport.parking: No dedicated parking; use public garages

general.name: Kunstpavillon im Alten Botanischen Garten
general.description: Run by the 'Schutzverband Bildender Künstler', the Kunstpavillon is an exhibition space located in the serene setting of the Old Botanical Garden near Karlsplatz. It serves as a forum for contemporary artists from Munich and Bavaria, hosting changing solo and group exhibitions. The historic pavilion, rebuilt after the war, offers a bright and intimate atmosphere for viewing paintings, sculptures, and installations.

general.name: Botanischer Garten München-Nymphenburg
general.description: One of the most important botanical gardens in the world, this sprawling site covers over 21 hectares and cultivates approximately 19,600 species of plants. Visitors can explore the extensive outdoor gardens, including the Alpineum and Arboretum, as well as the historic greenhouse complex which houses tropical plants, cacti, and giant water lilies. It is a center for botanical research and a popular recreational destination throughout the seasons.

offline.opening_hours: Daily. Winter: 9:00-16:30; Summer: 9:00-18:00 (Greenhouses close 30 min earlier)
offline.ticket_info: Regular: 5.50€ (Garden+Greenhouses); Reduced: 4€; Winter outdoor only: Free

general.name: Stadtmuseum Unterschleißheim
general.description: The Stadtmuseum Unterschleißheim documents the rapid development of the town from a rural village to a modern high-tech location. The permanent exhibition focuses on local history, archaeology, and the settlement of displaced persons after WWII. It regularly hosts special exhibitions on art and cultural history and offers educational programs for schools and families.

general.name: Museum Starnberger See
general.description: Housed in a historic farmhouse and a modern extension, this museum illustrates the lifestyle and history of the Lake Starnberg region. Exhibits cover courtly life on the lake (including the royal Wittelsbach fleet), fishing traditions, and the area's development as a villa suburb for Munich's elite. A highlight is the opulent 'Delphin' state barge from the 19th century.

general.name: FC Bayern Museum
general.description: Located inside the Allianz Arena, the FC Bayern Museum is Germany's largest club museum. It chronicles the history of FC Bayern Munich from its foundation in 1900 to its current status as a global superclub. Visitors can see the impressive trophy collection, historic jerseys, and learn about club legends like Franz Beckenbauer and Gerd Müller through interactive multimedia exhibits.

offline.ticket_info: Adults: 12€; Children (6-13): 6€; Combo with Arena Tour available

general.name: FC Bayern Museum
general.description: Located inside the Allianz Arena, the FC Bayern Museum is Germany's largest club museum. It chronicles the history of FC Bayern Munich from its foundation in 1900 to its current status as a global superclub. Visitors can see the impressive trophy collection, historic jerseys, and learn about club legends like Franz Beckenbauer and Gerd Müller through interactive multimedia exhibits.

offline.ticket_info: Adults: 12€; Children (6-13): 6€; Combo with Arena Tour available

general.name: Kunsthalle München
general.description: The Kunsthalle München, located in the 'Fünf Höfe' complex in the city center, is one of Germany's most prestigious exhibition houses. Without a permanent collection of its own, it hosts high-caliber temporary exhibitions ranging from photography and fashion to painting and design. Organized by the Hypo-Kulturstiftung, the shows often feature international loans and cover diverse themes from the Old Masters to contemporary avant-garde.

offline.event: Major temporary art exhibitions (e.g., Flowers, Viktor & Rolf)

general.name: Architekturmuseum der TU München (Architecture Museum)
general.description: Located within the Pinakothek der Moderne, the Architekturmuseum der TUM holds the largest special collection of architecture in Germany. It presents changing exhibitions on the history of architecture, current building projects, and urban planning issues. Drawing from an archive of over 500,000 plans and models, the museum explores the social and artistic dimensions of the built environment.

offline.ticket_info: Included in Pinakothek der Moderne ticket (10€)
offline.event: Exhibitions on modern and historic architecture

general.name: NS-Dokumentationszentrum München (Munich Documentation Centre for the History of National Socialism)
general.description: Built on the site of the former 'Brown House' (Nazi Party headquarters), this documentation center examines Munich's role as the 'Capital of the Movement'. The permanent exhibition addresses the rise of National Socialism, the mechanisms of the dictatorship, and the city's difficulties in dealing with this past after 1945. It is a central place of learning and remembrance, offering educational programs and special exhibitions.

general.name: Galerie Bezirk Oberbayern
general.description: This gallery specializes in inclusive art projects and the work of artists with disabilities ('Outsider Art'), as well as contemporary regional art. Located in the administrative building of the District of Upper Bavaria, it aims to foster dialogue and dismantle social barriers through art. Exhibitions are often accompanied by inclusive educational programs, including tours in sign language.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; street parking limited

general.name: Rathausgalerie Kunsthalle
general.description: Located directly under the arcades of the New Town Hall on Marienplatz, the Rathausgalerie is a municipal art space with a bright glass dome. It focuses on contemporary art by artists living or working in Munich, covering painting, photography, and installation art. The central location makes it a spontaneous meeting point for art lovers in the heart of the city.

general.name: Vermessen in Bayern - Vermessungshistorische Ausstellung
general.description: Housed in the State Office for Digitization, Broadband and Surveying, this exhibition showcases the history of surveying in Bavaria. Highlights include the original lithographic stones used by Alois Senefelder and historical measuring instruments like the famous Fraunhofer telescope. It tells the story of how Bavaria became the first completely surveyed state in Europe in the 19th century.

offline.opening_hours: Mon-Thu 9:00-16:00, Fri 9:00-14:00 (Check website, often by appt)

general.name: Kunstarkaden
general.description: The Kunstarkaden is a municipal gallery space devoted to experimental contemporary art. It provides a platform for young and emerging artists, often showing group exhibitions that cross different media and genres. Located near the Viktualienmarkt, the space encourages discourse on current artistic trends and societal themes.

general.name: MUCA (Museum of Urban and Contemporary Art)
general.description: MUCA is Germany's first museum dedicated to urban and street art, located in a former municipal substation. The museum aims to bridge the gap between street art and traditional art history, showcasing works by stars like Banksy, Shepard Fairey, and Vhils. It also commissions large-scale outdoor murals and hosts educational workshops to promote the understanding of art in public spaces.

offline.event: Street art exhibitions and mural tours

general.name: Kunstlabor 2
general.description: Kunstlabor 2 is a massive interim cultural project run by the MUCA team, located in a former health department building. Over 100 artists have transformed the rooms and facade into a walk-in work of art, featuring graffiti, installations, and immersive rooms. It serves as a creative hub with studios, exhibition spaces, and a restaurant, offering a unique experimental art experience.

offline.event: Immersive art rooms and mural viewing

general.name: Münchner Sanitätsmuseum (Rotkreuz-Museum)
general.description: This museum documents the history of the Red Cross in Munich and the development of emergency medical services. Exhibits include historic ambulances, uniforms, medical equipment, and documents from both World Wars. **Note: The museum is currently reported as closed or open only by appointment.** It is maintained by volunteers of the Bavarian Red Cross.

general.name: Deutsches Theatermuseum (German Theatre Museum)
general.description: Located in the historic 'Churfürstliche Galerie' at the Hofgarten, the Deutsches Theatermuseum preserves one of the world's most extensive collections of theatre history. It holds photographs, stage models, costumes, and props documenting the performing arts from the Renaissance to the present. The museum presents changing exhibitions on actors, directors, stage design, and theatrical eras.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

general.name: Infopoint Museen & Schlösser in Bayern
general.description: Located in the Alter Hof, close to Marienplatz, the Infopoint serves as the central information hub for all state and non-state museums and palaces in Bavaria. Visitors can get free advice, brochures, and information about current exhibitions across the region. It is situated in the same building as the 'Münchner Kaiserburg' multimedia exhibition, making it a good starting point for cultural tourists.

general.name: Verkehrszentrum des Deutschen Museums (Transport Centre)
general.description: Located in three historic exhibition halls on the Theresienhöhe, the Verkehrszentrum is the branch of the Deutsches Museum dedicated to land transport. It explores the history and future of mobility, displaying trains, cars, bicycles, and public transport vehicles. Highlights include the first Benz motorwagen, the Puffing Billy locomotive, and exhibitions on urban mobility and traffic infrastructure.

transport.parking: No dedicated parking; use Theresienwiese public parking

general.name: KZ-Gedenkstätte Dachau (Dachau Concentration Camp Memorial Site)
general.description: Established on the grounds of the former concentration camp, this memorial is a place of remembrance and education. The site preserves the original layout including the Jourhaus, the bunker, the crematorium area, and reconstructed barracks. The main exhibition traces the history of the camp, the suffering of the prisoners, and the system of Nazi terror. It is a solemn site dedicated to the memory of over 41,000 people who died here.

offline.ticket_info: Free admission; Audio guide: ~4€; Parking fee applies

transport.parking: Paid parking lot at the entrance

general.name: Kallmann-Museum Ismaning
general.description: Located in the Schloss Ismaning park, this museum is dedicated to the work of painter Hans Jürgen Kallmann (1908-1991). In addition to his portraits and paintings, the museum presents modern and contemporary art exhibitions, often with a thematic focus on portraits or nature. The architecture of the museum, built in the style of an orangery, integrates beautifully with the surrounding parkland.

general.name: Internationale Jugendbibliothek (International Youth Library)
general.description: Housed in the picturesque Blutenburg Castle, the International Youth Library is the world's largest library for international children's and youth literature. It features several literary museums, including the Michael Ende Museum, the James Krüss Tower, and the Binette Schröder Cabinet. Visitors can explore the castle grounds, attend readings, and view exhibitions of book illustrations.

offline.opening_hours: Museums: Wed-Sun 14:00-17:00 (Check individual museum times); Library: Mon-Fri

general.name: PLATFORM
general.description: PLATFORM is a municipal art space and competence center for cultural workers, located in a former industrial building in Obersendling. It offers exhibition spaces for contemporary art projects and studios for artists and curators. The focus is on innovative, interdisciplinary, and socially relevant art forms, often providing a stage for young and less established artists in Munich.

general.name: Bayerisches Hauptstaatsarchiv
general.description: The Bayerisches Hauptstaatsarchiv is the central archive for the Free State of Bavaria, responsible for the records of the former Duchy, Electorate, and Kingdom of Bavaria. It preserves millions of documents, including deeds, maps, and files dating back to the early Middle Ages. The archive regularly hosts historical exhibitions that showcase its vast treasures, providing deep insights into Bavarian and European history. It serves as a crucial resource for researchers and historians.

offline.opening_hours: Mon-Thu 8:30-18:30 (Reading rooms close 16:00), Fri 8:30-13:30; Closed Sat-Sun

general.name: Archäologische Staatssammlung (State Archaeological Collection)
general.description: The Archäologische Staatssammlung is the central museum for prehistory and early history in Bavaria. Following a comprehensive general renovation, it presents the cultural development of humanity in Bavaria from the Stone Age to the early Middle Ages. The new permanent exhibition features spectacular finds, including Celtic gold treasure and Roman artifacts, displayed in a modern, thematic setting. Interactive stations and media guides make the distant past accessible to visitors of all ages. The museum also serves as a research center for Bavarian archaeology.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

general.name: AschheiMuseum
general.description: The AschheiMuseum focuses on the local history and archaeological heritage of Aschheim and its surroundings. It presents finds ranging from prehistoric settlements to Roman and medieval periods. Exhibitions emphasize everyday life, burial culture, and regional development. The museum works closely with archaeological research institutions. Educational formats make complex historical topics accessible to all age groups. It serves as an important cultural memory space for the local community.

offline.event: Local history exhibitions, guided tours, community events

general.name: Burgmuseum Grünwald (Grünwald Castle Museum)
general.description: Located in the only medieval castle in the Munich area, the Burgmuseum Grünwald is a branch of the Archäologische Staatssammlung. The exhibition 'Castles in Bavaria' explains the function and history of castles, showcasing armor, weapons, and everyday medieval objects. Visitors can climb the castle tower for a stunning view of the Isar valley and explore the historic castle grounds. It serves as an educational site for medieval history and castle architecture. The castle also hosts changing special exhibitions related to regional history.

general.name: Galerie der Künstler (BBK)
general.description: Run by the Professional Association of Visual Artists (BBK) Munich and Upper Bavaria, this gallery is a key platform for contemporary art production in the region. Located in the Museum Fünf Kontinente building, it presents experimental and innovative works by local artists, including the annual debutant exhibition. The gallery fosters professional exchange and offers visibility to emerging talents in the Munich art scene. Its program includes painting, sculpture, installation, and media art. Admission is often free or very affordable to encourage broad public engagement.

offline.event: Contemporary art exhibitions by BBK members

general.name: Staatliche Antikensammlungen (State Collections of Antiquities)
general.description: Facing the Glyptothek on Königsplatz, the Staatliche Antikensammlungen houses one of the world's most significant collections of Greek, Etruscan, and Roman minor arts. The museum is renowned for its outstanding collection of Greek vases, as well as ancient jewelry, bronzes, and glass. The building itself, a neo-classical temple designed by Georg Friedrich Ziebland, provides a fitting backdrop for these ancient treasures. It regularly hosts high-quality special exhibitions on various aspects of the ancient world. The museum forms a core part of Munich's Kunstareal.

offline.event: Exhibitions on Greek, Roman, and Etruscan art

general.name: Monacensia im Hildebrandhaus
general.description: The Monacensia is the literary archive and library of the City of Munich, housed in the historic artist's villa of Adolf von Hildebrand. It preserves the literary estate of famous Munich writers such as Thomas Mann, Klaus Mann, and Oskar Maria Graf. The permanent exhibition 'Literary Munich at the Time of Thomas Mann' explores the city's intellectual life from the turn of the century to the 1920s. With its beautiful garden and café, it serves as a vibrant meeting place for literature lovers. The institution also hosts readings, discussions, and temporary exhibitions.

general.name: Amerikahaus München
general.description: The Amerikahaus Munich is a Bavarian-American cultural institution dedicated to transatlantic dialogue. It hosts a diverse program of exhibitions, theater performances, concerts, and lectures focused on American culture, politics, and society. The building itself is a protected historical monument and has played a key role in Munich's post-war cultural landscape. It also houses a library and information center. The institution acts as a bridge between Bavaria and North America.

offline.event: Exhibitions on US culture and photography

general.name: Museum Brandhorst
general.description: Opened in 2009, Museum Brandhorst is a masterpiece of contemporary architecture housing a significant collection of modern and contemporary art. It features the world's largest collection of works by Cy Twombly, as well as extensive holdings of Andy Warhol. The building, known for its colorful ceramic facade, presents art from the 1960s to the present day in spacious, light-filled galleries. The museum is part of the Kunstareal and focuses on painting, sculpture, and photography. It regularly presents thematic special exhibitions.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

general.name: Museum Villa Stuck
general.description: The Museum Villa Stuck is located in the historic home and studio of the artist Franz von Stuck, a prince of painters. The villa itself is a Gesamtkunstwerk (total work of art) of the Jugendstil/Art Nouveau period, with lavishly decorated historic rooms. It houses a collection of Stuck's works and presents high-profile temporary exhibitions on art from around 1900 to contemporary design and photography. The museum highlights the intersection of life and art in a unique architectural setting. It also features a lovely garden and cafe.

offline.opening_hours: Tue-Sun 11:00-18:00, First Friday of month 11:00-22:00; Closed Mon
offline.event: Jugendstil architecture and contemporary art exhibitions

general.name: Archiv Geiger
general.description: The Archiv Geiger preserves the artistic estate of Rupprecht Geiger, one of Germany's most important post-war abstract painters. Located in his former studio in Munich-Solln, the archive offers a unique insight into his work with color, particularly his signature fluorescent pigments. Visitors can see original materials, sketches, and finished works in the authentic setting where they were created. The archive organizes guided tours, workshops, and exhibitions to keep Geiger's legacy alive. Access is typically by appointment or during scheduled events.

offline.opening_hours: Mon 10:00-14:00, Tue 17:00-20:00; Other times by appointment
offline.event: Guided tours through the artist's studio

general.name: Kunstraum München
general.description: Founded in 1973, Kunstraum München is one of the city's oldest non-profit associations for contemporary art. Located in the Glockenbachviertel, it focuses on exhibiting and documenting international contemporary art. The program features solo and group shows, often emphasizing conceptual and project-based work. It serves as a space for discourse and experimentation, publishing catalogues and editions to accompany its exhibitions. The intimate gallery setting encourages close engagement with the art.

general.name: Pasinger Fabrik
general.description: Located in a former household goods factory next to Pasing station, Pasinger Fabrik is a vibrant municipal cultural center. It houses theaters, exhibition galleries, and artists' studios, offering a diverse program of performing and visual arts. The galleries present changing exhibitions on photography, contemporary art, and cultural history. It is also known for its 'Münchens kleinstes Opernhaus' (Munich's smallest opera house) and a popular restaurant/bar. The center serves as a cultural hub for the western districts of Munich.

offline.opening_hours: Galleries: Tue-Sun 16:00-20:00 (Check website for specific exhibitions)

general.name: Kunstfoyer (Versicherungskammer Kulturstiftung)
general.description: The Kunstfoyer is the exhibition space of the Versicherungskammer Kulturstiftung, known for its outstanding photography exhibitions. Located near the Maximilianstraße, it presents retrospectives of internationally renowned photographers as well as documentary film projects. The foundation aims to make art and culture accessible to a broad public, often focusing on socially relevant themes. Admission to all exhibitions is free, making it a popular destination for photography enthusiasts. The space offers a high-quality setting for visual arts.

general.name: Zentralinstitut für Kunstgeschichte (Central Institute for Art History)
general.description: Housed in the former Nazi administrative building on Königsplatz, the Zentralinstitut für Kunstgeschichte is a world-renowned research institute. While primarily a research facility with one of the world's largest art libraries, it regularly hosts public exhibitions and lectures. The exhibitions often focus on art historical topics, photography, or the architectural history of the building itself. The institute plays a critical role in the provenance research and the study of art history in Germany. Visitors can also view the historic atrium and the 'Lichthof'.

general.name: Bayerisches Nationalmuseum (Bavarian National Museum)
general.description: One of the most important museums of decorative arts and cultural history in Europe, located on Prinzregentenstraße. Its collections span from late antiquity to Art Nouveau, featuring sculptures, tapestries, furniture, porcelain, and fashion. Highlights include the world-famous collection of nativity scenes (Krippensammlung) and the Bollert Collection of medieval sculpture. The building itself is a historicist monument, providing an atmospheric setting for the diverse artifacts. It illustrates the art and cultural history of Bavaria and Europe over two millennia.

offline.event: Nativity scenes and cultural history exhibitions

general.name: ERES Stiftung
general.description: The ERES Foundation is a unique institution that fosters the dialogue between science and the fine arts. Through exhibitions, lectures, and publications, it explores scientific themes such as biology, physics, and astronomy through an artistic lens. The foundation provides a platform for artists who engage with scientific questions and for scientists interested in artistic perspectives. Located in Schwabing, it offers a stimulating intellectual environment. Admission to its events and exhibitions is typically free.

general.name: Gemäldegalerie Dachau
general.description: The Gemäldegalerie Dachau focuses on the history of the Dachau artists' colony, which was one of the most significant in Europe around 1900. It presents works by famous landscape painters like Adolf Hölzel, Ludwig Dill, and Arthur Langhammer who were drawn to the atmospheric Dachau moorlands. The museum illustrates the development of open-air painting (Plein Air) in the region. Special exhibitions highlight specific artists or themes related to the colony's history. It is a key stop for art lovers visiting the historic town of Dachau.

offline.event: Exhibitions on the Dachau Artists' Colony

general.name: Galerie GEDOK muc
general.description: The Galerie GEDOK muc is the exhibition space of the GEDOK München, the largest network for female artists in Germany. It showcases works by its members across various disciplines, including fine arts, applied arts, and multimedia. The gallery promotes the visibility of women in the art world and fosters interdisciplinary exchange through exhibitions, concerts, and readings. Located in the Schleißheimer Straße, it is an active hub for feminist and contemporary art discourse.

general.name: Literaturhaus München
general.description: Located at Salvatorplatz in the city center, the Literaturhaus München is a vibrant venue dedicated to the world of books and authors. It hosts a rich program of readings, discussions, and literary festivals featuring international and local writers. The building also contains exhibition spaces that present literary themes in visual formats. With its popular brasserie 'OskarMaria', it serves as a central meeting point for Munich's intellectual and cultural scene. The institution actively promotes reading culture and literary debate.

offline.event: Readings, book premieres, and literary exhibitions

general.name: SchichtWerk - Zeitreisen im Wersonhaus
general.description: Located in the historic Wersonhaus in Gilching, the SchichtWerk museum invites visitors on a fascinating journey through time. The exhibition focuses on the rich archaeological heritage of the region, from the Stone Age and the Roman period to the early Middle Ages. Highlights include the reconstruction of a Roman kiln and findings from the Via Julia, which ran through the area. Interactive displays and hands-on stations make the history of settlement in the Five Lakes Region tangible for all ages. The museum also explores the local history of Gilching, documenting its transformation from a rural village to a modern municipality. It is run by a dedicated association that organizes regular lectures and special events to bring the past to life.

transport.parking: Parking available at the town hall or nearby

offline.event: Living history days and archaeological workshops

general.name: Städtische Galerie im Lenbachhaus und Kunstbau
general.description: The Lenbachhaus is world-renowned for housing the largest collection of art by the 'Blue Rider' (Der Blaue Reiter) group, including masterpieces by Wassily Kandinsky, Gabriele Münter, and Franz Marc. Located in the historic villa of the artist prince Franz von Lenbach, the museum was expanded with a striking golden wing by Norman Foster. In addition to Expressionism, the collection features 19th-century Munich landscape paintings and a significant array of international contemporary art. The underground 'Kunstbau' located in the subway mezzanine serves as a spectacular venue for large-scale temporary exhibitions. The museum's unique combination of historic architecture and modern design creates a perfect setting for its diverse artistic treasures. Visitors can also enjoy the beautiful garden and the acclaimed museum restaurant, ELLA.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

offline.event: Blue Rider exhibitions and contemporary art installations

general.name: Haus der Kunst
general.description: The Haus der Kunst is a leading international center for contemporary art, located on the edge of the English Garden. Originally built in the National Socialist era as a 'House of German Art', it has transformed into a global platform for avant-garde and experimental works, critically engaging with its own history. The museum does not hold a permanent collection but hosts rotating exhibitions of major international artists, covering painting, sculpture, photography, and performance art. Its monumental architecture provides vast spaces for large-scale installations that few other institutions can accommodate. The 'Golden Bar' inside is a historic and popular meeting spot for museum-goers and locals alike. It is dedicated to exploring diverse global perspectives and fostering cultural dialogue.

offline.opening_hours: Mon, Wed, Fri-Sun 10:00-20:00, Thu 10:00-22:00; Closed Tue

transport.parking: Paid parking lot behind the building

offline.event: Major contemporary art retrospectives and performance events

general.name: Museum Fünf Kontinente (Museum Five Continents)
general.description: Founded in 1862 as the first ethnological museum in Germany, the Museum Fünf Kontinente houses a vast collection of artworks and cultural objects from outside Europe. The exhibitions take visitors on a journey through the cultures of Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia, and the Oceania region. Highlights include the famous 'Blue Room' with Chinese porcelain, Native American artifacts, and Benin bronzes. The museum aims to promote understanding and respect between different cultures through its displays and educational programs. It addresses current debates on colonialism and provenance, actively engaging in the restitution of cultural heritage. Special exhibitions often focus on contemporary issues and global interconnectedness.

offline.event: Exhibitions on global cultures and ethnology

general.name: Deutsches Jagd- und Fischereimuseum (German Hunting and Fishing Museum)
general.description: Located in the former Augustinian Church in the heart of Munich's pedestrian zone, this museum is dedicated to the cultural history of hunting and fishing. Famous for the bronze boar and catfish statues at its entrance, the museum displays a vast collection of historic weapons, hunting trophies, and fishing tackle. Detailed dioramas present native wildlife in their natural habitats, offering insights into biology and conservation. The museum also explores the mythological and artistic representation of hunting throughout the centuries, featuring works by renowned painters. Interactive exhibits educate visitors on the ecological role of hunters and fishermen today. It is a unique blend of cultural history and natural science.

offline.event: Special exhibitions on wildlife and nature

general.name: Sudetendeutsches Museum
general.description: Perched on the high bank of the Isar river, the Sudetendeutsches Museum is a modern architectural landmark dedicated to the history of the German-speaking population in the Bohemian Lands. The permanent exhibition spans over 1,100 years, chronicling the cultural, economic, and social life of Germans in Bohemia, Moravia, and Sudeten Silesia. It vividly portrays the tragic events of the 20th century, focusing on the flight and expulsion of millions after World War II and their subsequent integration into post-war Germany. Through personal artifacts, multimedia stations, and art, the museum fosters a culture of remembrance and dialogue in the heart of Europe. It serves as a bridge to the present-day Czech Republic and a center for understanding displacement. The museum is barrier-free and offers panoramic views of Munich.

transport.parking: Garage at the museum or Motorama

general.name: Die Neue Sammlung - The Design Museum (Pinakothek der Moderne)
general.description: Die Neue Sammlung is widely regarded as the oldest and one of the most significant design museums in the world. Housed within the Pinakothek der Moderne, it boasts a collection of over 100,000 objects ranging from industrial design and graphic design to applied arts. The permanent exhibition showcases milestones of design history, including automotive design, furniture, and computer technology, often presented in spectacular installations like the 'Paternoster' wall. It explores the evolution of everyday objects and their impact on society and culture throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The museum regularly invites contemporary designers to curate site-specific installations, keeping the dialogue on design lively and current. A highlight is the Futuro House located outside the museum entrance.

offline.event: Major design exhibitions and X-D-E-P-O-T displays

general.name: Sammlung Moderne Kunst (Pinakothek der Moderne)
general.description: The Sammlung Moderne Kunst is one of the leading collections of 20th and 21st-century art in Germany, forming a central pillar of the Pinakothek der Moderne. It covers all major artistic movements of the modern era, from Expressionism, Cubism, and New Objectivity to Pop Art and Minimalism. Visitors can admire masterpieces by artists such as Max Beckmann, Pablo Picasso, Andy Warhol, and Gerhard Richter. The collection also places a strong emphasis on contemporary photography and new media art, constantly expanding its horizons. The thematic presentation of works encourages dialogue between different eras and styles, offering fresh perspectives on art history. It occupies the spacious upper floor of the building, bathed in natural light.

general.name: Staatliche Graphische Sammlung München (Pinakothek der Moderne)
general.description: With over 400,000 works, the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung München is one of the most important collections of drawings and prints in the world. Its holdings span from the Middle Ages to the present day, featuring works by masters like Dürer, Rembrandt, Michelangelo, and Picasso. Due to the sensitivity of paper to light, the works are not shown in a permanent display but are presented in changing temporary exhibitions within the Pinakothek der Moderne. These exhibitions often highlight specific artists, techniques, or themes, offering intimate insights into the drafting skills of great artists. The museum also maintains a study room where scholars and the public can view specific works by appointment. It serves as a center for the appreciation and study of graphic arts.

offline.event: Temporary exhibitions of drawings and prints

general.name: Glyptothek
general.description: The Glyptothek is Munich's oldest public museum and houses one of the world's most significant collections of ancient Greek and Roman sculpture. Commissioned by King Ludwig I, the neo-classical building itself is a work of art, designed to emulate an ancient temple. The collection includes masterpieces such as the pediment figures from the Temple of Aphaia at Aegina, the Barberini Faun, and portraits of Roman emperors. After extensive renovations, the sculptures are presented in a pure and minimalist setting, allowing the marble to speak for itself. The museum's inner courtyard provides a tranquil oasis with a cafe, perfect for reflection amidst the art. It stands on the Königsplatz, forming a unique ensemble of classical architecture with the neighboring Antikensammlungen.

offline.opening_hours: Tue, Wed, Fri-Sun 10:00-17:00, Thu 10:00-20:00; Closed Mon

general.name: Alte Pinakothek
general.description: The Alte Pinakothek is one of the oldest and most significant art galleries in the world, renowned for its collection of Old Master paintings. Commissioned by King Ludwig I, the neo-Renaissance building houses over 700 works from the 14th to the 18th centuries. Highlights include Dürer's 'Four Apostles', Rubens' 'Judgment of Paris', and masterpieces by Raphael, Titian, and Rembrandt. The gallery offers a comprehensive overview of the development of painting in Europe, from the Middle Ages to the Rococo. It is a cornerstone of the Kunstareal Munich.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

general.name: Kindermuseum München
general.description: Located in the Starnberger Flügelbahnhof of Munich Central Station, the Kindermuseum offers interactive exhibitions designed specifically for children. Topics change regularly and cover areas such as science, technology, art, and culture, encouraging hands-on participation. The museum provides a creative space where kids can experiment, play, and learn about the world around them. Workshops and birthday parties are also part of the program. It is an ideal destination for families seeking educational entertainment.

general.name: Galerie Handwerk
general.description: Run by the Chamber of Trades for Munich and Upper Bavaria, the Galerie Handwerk showcases high-quality contemporary crafts and applied arts. Through roughly seven exhibitions per year, it presents works in ceramics, glass, jewelry, textile, and wood from international artists. The gallery aims to promote the appreciation of craftsmanship and design excellence. It is located near the Bavarian National Museum and the English Garden. Admission to the exhibitions is typically free.

general.name: Heimatmuseum Karlsfeld
general.description: The Heimatmuseum Karlsfeld documents the history of the municipality, focusing on the settlement of the 'Ludwigsfelder Moos' and the integration of refugees after World War II. Exhibits include household items, agricultural tools, and documents illustrating the development of the community from a peat-cutting settlement to a modern suburb. Special attention is given to the history of the Allach porcelain manufactory and local associations. The museum serves as a repository for local identity and memory.

general.name: Sammlung Goetz
general.description: The Sammlung Goetz is an internationally renowned private collection of contemporary art, featuring works by artists such as Mike Kelley, Rosemarie Trockel, and Matthew Barney. While the main building in Oberföhring (designed by Herzog & de Meuron) is currently closed for renovation, the collection is presented in changing exhibitions at temporary locations and partner institutions. The current interim space is **Sammlung Goetz / Schaufenster** in the city center. The collection focuses on Arte Povera, media art, and young contemporary positions.

offline.opening_hours: Tue-Sat varies (Check website); Main building closed

general.name: Sammlung Café Luitpold
general.description: Located within the historic Café Luitpold, this small museum documents the coffeehouse culture of Munich. Photographs, menus, and objects tell the story of the café since its opening in 1888, when it was a meeting place for artists and writers like Kandinsky and Rilke. The exhibition highlights the café's role as a social hub and its architectural evolution. It is accessible to café guests during opening hours.

general.name: Deutsches Museum
general.description: The Deutsches Museum is one of the world's largest and most famous museums of science and technology. Located on an island in the Isar river, it houses thousands of exhibits ranging from mining and aerospace to physics and musical instruments. Interactive demonstrations, such as the high-voltage show, and historic artifacts like the first automobile by Benz, make it a fascinating experience. The museum is currently undergoing a massive modernization, but many exhibitions remain open.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; use public transport

general.name: Schloss Nymphenburg (Nymphenburg Palace)
general.description: Nymphenburg Palace was the summer residence of the Bavarian rulers and is one of the largest baroque palace complexes in Europe. Visitors can explore the magnificent Steinerner Saal (Stone Hall), the Gallery of Beauties commissioned by King Ludwig I, and the birth room of King Ludwig II. The palace is surrounded by a vast park with park pavilions, canals, and fountains. It offers a glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of the Wittelsbach dynasty.

offline.opening_hours: Apr-Mid Oct: Daily 9:00-18:00; Mid Oct-Mar: Daily 10:00-16:00
offline.ticket_info: Regular: 8€; Reduced: 7€ (Palace only); Combo tickets available

general.name: Zeit + Raum Museum
general.description: The 'Zeit + Raum Museum' in Grafing serves as the town's museum, library, and archive. It presents the history of the Grafing region through exhibitions on archaeology, local history, and art. The museum is located in a historic building and organizes regular special exhibitions, lectures, and cultural events. It acts as a community hub for preserving and sharing local heritage.

general.name: Paläontologisches Museum München
general.description: Part of the Bavarian State Collection of Paleontology and Geology, this museum showcases fossils and skeletons of prehistoric animals. Highlights include the skeleton of the 'Mühldorf Elephant' (Gomphotherium), a large pterosaur, and the Archaeopteryx bavarica. The museum explains the evolution of life on Earth and geological history. It is a university museum open to the public, offering free admission.

offline.event: Special openings on first Sundays with tours

general.name: Heimat- und Torfmuseum Gröbenzell
general.description: This museum documents the history of Gröbenzell, focusing on peat extraction and the life of the 'Moos' settlers. It features a replica of a historic peat cutter's living room and tools used for peat mining. Exhibits also cover the geological development of the moorland. The museum preserves the memory of the hard labor and living conditions in the Dachauer Moos.

general.name: Seidlvilla
general.description: The Seidlvilla is a vibrant cultural center located in a historic villa in Schwabing. It hosts a wide variety of events including concerts, readings, lectures, and exhibitions. The house also offers workshops and serves as a meeting place for local initiatives. The beautiful garden and the heritage-protected building provide a charming atmosphere for cultural engagement.

offline.ticket_info: Exhibitions usually free; Event prices vary

general.name: Säulenhalle des Bayerischen Landesamts für Denkmalpflege
general.description: The Säulenhalle (Columned Hall) in the Old Mint (Alte Münze) is used by the Bavarian State Office for Monument Preservation for exhibitions. These exhibitions focus on archaeology, architectural conservation, and Bavarian history. The Renaissance arcade courtyard of the building is an architectural highlight in itself. The venue serves to educate the public about the importance of preserving cultural heritage.

general.name: Schloss Lustheim - Meißener Porzellan-Sammlung
general.description: Located in the Schleißheim Palace Park, Schloss Lustheim houses the world-renowned Ernst Schneider Collection of early Meissen porcelain. The exhibition showcases over 2,000 exquisite pieces, including dinner services, centerpieces, and animal figures, in the setting of a baroque hunting lodge. The ceiling frescoes in the banquet hall are also a major attraction. It offers a comprehensive view of the first European porcelain manufactory's golden age.

general.name: Staatliche Münzsammlung München
general.description: The Staatliche Münzsammlung is one of the leading numismatic collections in Europe, with over 300,000 objects. It displays coins, medals, banknotes, and cut stones from antiquity to the present day. Exhibits cover the history of money, the art of the medal, and the symbolism of coinage. Located in the Munich Residence, it serves as a center for research and education on monetary history.

transport.parking: No visitor parking; public garages nearby

offline.event: Special exhibitions on coins and medals

general.name: Geologisches Museum München
general.description: This museum provides insights into the geological history of Bavaria and the Alps. It displays rocks, minerals, and fossils that illustrate the formation of the earth's crust and regional geology. Key exhibits include the geology of the Ries crater and the development of the Alpine landscape. It is part of the Ludwig Maximilian University and aims to educate the public on earth sciences.

offline.opening_hours: Mon-Thu 8:00-16:00, Fri 8:00-14:00; Closed Sat-Sun (except special events)

general.name: BMW Museum
general.description: The BMW Museum brings the history of the BMW brand to life, showcasing over 100 years of automotive innovation. Located near the Olympic Park, the museum's dynamic architecture houses engines, turbines, aircraft, motorcycles, and automobiles. Visitors can explore the brand's milestones, design evolution, and future mobility concepts. The 'Museum Bowl' and the neighboring BMW Welt create a comprehensive automotive experience.

general.name: Hoamatstubn des Trachtenvereins Georgenstoana
general.description: The 'Hoamatstubn' is a small local heritage museum run by the traditional costume association 'Georgenstoana' in Baierbrunn. It preserves and displays objects related to local customs, traditional costumes (Tracht), and rural life in the Isar valley. The collection includes historic garments, photographs, and tools. It serves as a meeting point for maintaining Bavarian traditions and is open on specific occasions.

offline.opening_hours: By appointment and during club events

general.name: Bier- und Oktoberfestmuseum
general.description: Housed in one of Munich's oldest townhouses dating back to 1327, this museum is dedicated to the history of beer brewing and the Oktoberfest. Exhibits cover the purity law, the evolution of Munich's breweries, and the development of the world-famous beer festival. The rustic atmosphere of the historic building enhances the experience. Visitors can also enjoy a beer in the museum stüberl (pub) on the ground floor.

general.name: Psychiatrie-Museum im kbo-Isar-Amper-Klinikum München-Ost
general.description: Located on the grounds of the kbo-Isar-Amper-Klinikum in Haar, this museum documents the history of psychiatry from the 19th century to the present. It addresses the dark chapter of the Nazi 'euthanasia' program and the treatment of patients over the decades. Exhibits include medical equipment, patient artworks, and historical documents. The museum aims to destigmatize mental illness and educate about the evolution of psychiatric care.

offline.event: Guided tours on history of psychiatry

general.name: Neues Schloss Schleißheim
general.description: The New Palace Schleißheim is a grand baroque palace built by Elector Max Emanuel, intended to rival Versailles. It features an impressive sequence of state rooms, the Great Hall, and the Victory Hall, decorated with frescoes and stucco. The palace houses the State Gallery of European Baroque Painting. The surrounding baroque garden with its canals and fountains is one of the few preserved in its original style in Europe.

general.name: Münchner Bank Museum
general.description: The Münchner Bank Museum illustrates the history of Munich's oldest cooperative bank and the development of banking in the region. Exhibits include historical currencies, savings books, office equipment, and documents dating back to the bank's founding in 1862. It provides an interesting perspective on the economic history of Munich and the cooperative movement. Access is typically by appointment.

general.name: Museum der Marianischen Männerkongregation
general.description: Located in the Bürgersaal church, this museum is dedicated to the history of the Marian Men's Congregation and the life of Blessed Pater Rupert Mayer. Exhibits include personal items of Rupert Mayer, a resolute opponent of the Nazi regime, as well as religious art and documents of the congregation. The Bürgersaal itself is a significant baroque building and a place of pilgrimage.

offline.opening_hours: Daily 8:00-17:00 (Church); Museum varies, often on request

general.name: Heimatmuseum Unterhaching
general.description: The Heimatmuseum Unterhaching presents the history of the Haching Valley from prehistory to the present. The collection includes archaeological finds from early settlements, artifacts of rural life, and exhibits on the development of the modern municipality. A special focus is on local costumes and crafts. The museum is run by a local association and offers regular open days.

general.name: Denkstätte Weiße Rose
general.description: Located in the main building of the Ludwig Maximilian University (LMU), this memorial commemorates the student resistance group 'White Rose'. The permanent exhibition documents the group's history, their leaflets against the Nazi dictatorship, and their subsequent persecution and execution. It serves as a central place of remembrance and political education, right at the site where the Scholl siblings were arrested.

general.name: Lithographiesteinarchiv und druckhistorische Werkstätte
general.description: Located in the basement of the Münchner Künstlerhaus, this archive preserves a unique collection of lithographic stones. It documents the history of lithography, invented by Alois Senefelder in Munich. The workshop maintains historic printing presses and demonstrates the lithographic process. It serves as a living museum where the craft of stone printing is kept alive and explained to visitors.

general.name: Bajuwarenhof Kirchheim
general.description: The Bajuwarenhof is an open-air archaeological museum that reconstructs a typical early medieval settlement of the Bavarians (Bajuwaren). It features reconstructed wooden houses, gardens with historic plants, and demonstration areas for crafts. Based on local archaeological finds, it provides a vivid impression of life in the 6th to 8th centuries. Living history events regularly bring the settlement to life with costumed interpreters.

offline.address: Heimstettner Straße, 85551 Kirchheim bei München, Germany
offline.opening_hours: Sundays 14:00-17:00 (May-Oct); Winter closed or by appt

general.name: Zoologische Staatssammlung München
general.description: The Zoologische Staatssammlung is one of the world's largest research collections for zoology. While primarily a research institute not open to the public daily, it occasionally opens for lectures, special events, and guided tours organized by the 'Freunde der ZSM'. The collection holds millions of specimens from all animal groups, supporting biodiversity research globally. Its library and archives are significant resources for scientists.

offline.opening_hours: Not regularly open to public; Events only

general.name: Sammlung Schack
general.description: The Sammlung Schack is a gem of 19th-century German painting, housing the collection of Count Adolf Friedrich von Schack. It features famous works of German Romanticism, including masterpieces by Moritz von Schwind, Carl Spitzweg, and Arnold Böcklin. The gallery offers a journey into the world of legends, fairy tales, and idyllic landscapes cherished in the 19th century. It is part of the Bavarian State Painting Collections.

general.name: Residenz München Schatzkammer (Treasury)
general.description: The Treasury of the Munich Residence houses one of the most important collections of royal insignia and goldsmith's art in Europe. Spanning ten rooms, it displays over 1,200 masterpieces, including the Bavarian Crown Jewels, crystal goblets, and liturgical items. Highlights include the prayer book of Emperor Charles the Bald and the pearl-studded statuette of St. George. The collection reflects the power and wealth of the Wittelsbach dynasty over centuries.

offline.ticket_info: Regular: 10€; Reduced: 9€; Combo with Museum available
offline.event: Viewing of the Royal Crown Jewels

general.name: Ateliermuseum Magda Bittner-Simmet Stiftung
general.description: This museum preserves the studio and living quarters of the Munich painter Magda Bittner-Simmet (1916–2008) in their original state. Located at the English Garden, it offers an authentic glimpse into the life and work of a post-war female artist. The foundation organizes guided tours, readings, and small exhibitions that explore her oeuvre and the broader context of women in art. It is a hidden gem for those interested in artist studios.

offline.ticket_info: Guided tours fee applies; Registration required

general.name: Bayerischer Kunstgewerbeverein - Galerie für Angewandte Kunst
general.description: The Bayerischer Kunstgewerbeverein runs a gallery and shop in downtown Munich dedicated to contemporary applied arts. It presents changing exhibitions of high-quality crafts, including jewelry, ceramics, glass, and silverware by member artists. The association promotes the interface between art, craft, and design. The gallery serves as a platform for both established and emerging artisans to display and sell their unique works.

general.name: Alexander Tutsek-Stiftung
general.description: The Alexander Tutsek-Stiftung promotes contemporary art and science. Its exhibition spaces, the 'Villa' and 'BlackBox' in Schwabing, showcase diverse thematic exhibitions focusing on contemporary photography and glass sculpture. The foundation acquires works by international artists and supports art academies. The juxtaposition of glass art and photography creates a unique dialogue in their curated shows.

general.name: Siegfried Oberndorfer Sammlung
general.description: This teaching collection is housed in the Institute of Pathology at the Munich Clinic Schwabing. Named after Siegfried Oberndorfer, who first described carcinoid tumors, the collection contains historical pathological preparations and wax moulages. It serves primarily for medical education but offers a fascinating insight into the history of medicine and pathology. Public access is limited and usually requires an appointment or participation in specific guided tours.

general.name: VS - Das Interimsquartier des Museums Villa Stuck
general.description: While the historic Villa Stuck undergoes renovation (until 2025), the museum presents its program at 'VS' in Goethestraße. This interim location hosts exhibitions, events, and educational programs reflecting the spirit of the Villa Stuck in a new urban context. The focus remains on art from around 1900 to contemporary positions, adapted to the new space near the main station.

general.name: Heimatmuseum im Wolfschneiderhof
general.description: Located in a historic farmhouse, the Wolfschneiderhof presents rural life in the Haching Valley. The museum displays furnished rooms showing how farming families lived around 1900, along with agricultural tools and equipment. It serves as a cultural center for Taufkirchen, hosting exhibitions, traditional festivals, and educational activities about local history.

general.name: Deutsches Skimuseum (Haus des Ski)
general.description: Located in the 'Haus des Ski' of the German Ski Association (DSV), this museum preserves the history of skiing. It displays historic skis, bindings, boots, and clothing, documenting the evolution of winter sports from their origins to modern times. The collection also highlights the achievements of German ski athletes. It is a specialized museum for sports enthusiasts.

general.name: Haus der Ost- und Westpreußen
general.description: This institution is dedicated to preserving the cultural heritage of East and West Prussia. Through exhibitions of artifacts, maps, art, and literature, it keeps alive the memory of these former German provinces. It serves as a meeting place and educational center, organizing lectures and events that foster understanding of the history and expulsion of the Prussian Germans.

general.name: Borstei-Museum
general.description: The Borstei-Museum is located within the Borstei, a unique heritage-listed residential settlement built by Bernhard Borst in the 1920s. It documents the history and architectural concept of this 'city within a city', known for its gardens, art, and communal facilities. The museum displays plans, photos, and models, and often includes a visit to a preserved historic apartment. It offers a fascinating look at early 20th-century urban planning reform.

general.name: Museum Feringer Sach
general.description: The Museum Feringer Sach presents the local history of Unterföhring. It showcases archaeological finds from the region, tracing settlement back to the Stone Age and the Bavarian period. The exhibition also covers the development of the village into a modern media location. It is a community museum that preserves local heritage through artifacts and models.

general.name: Villa Rustica Leutstetten
general.description: The Villa Rustica in Leutstetten is the excavated remains of a Roman agricultural estate from the 2nd century AD. Visitors can see the preserved foundations of the main house and bathhouse, which provide insight into Roman rural life in Bavaria. The site is accessible year-round as an open-air museum, with information panels explaining the layout and function of the buildings. Guided tours are offered during the summer months.

offline.opening_hours: Always accessible (Open Air); Tours May-Oct 1st Sun 15:00

general.name: Heimathaus Neuchl-Anwesen
general.description: The Heimathaus Neuchl-Anwesen is a preserved farmhouse dating back to the mid-19th century. It houses the local history museum of Hohenschäftlarn, displaying furniture, household items, and tools that illustrate rural life in the region. The authentic atmosphere of the parlor, kitchen, and chambers offers a journey back in time. The museum is run by a local association committed to preserving village history.

general.name: Münchner Polizeimuseum
general.description: Located within the Munich Police Headquarters, this collection documents the history of the Munich police force. It covers over 100 years of police work, including spectacular criminal cases like the 1972 Olympics attack and the 'Isar 12' era. Exhibits include uniforms, weapons, and technical equipment. **Note:** Access is generally restricted and mostly possible through scheduled guided tours or special events like the 'Long Night of Museums'.

general.name: Erwin von Kreibig-Museum
general.description: Located in the south cavalier building of Nymphenburg Palace, this small museum is dedicated to the work of the Munich artist Erwin von Kreibig (1904–1961). It displays his paintings, drawings, and illustrations, often characterizing the Munich art scene of his time. The museum also hosts changing exhibitions of other regional artists. It offers a quiet, artistic stop within the bustling palace grounds.

general.name: Kunstsammlung des Herzoglichen Georgianums
general.description: The Herzogliches Georgianum, a theological seminary, houses a significant collection of religious art. The museum displays paintings, sculptures, and liturgical objects from the Middle Ages to the 19th century. Highlights include late Gothic panel paintings and baroque sculptures. It offers visitors a deep insight into the intersection of faith and art in Bavarian history. The museum is located prominently opposite the LMU main building.
